docs.lead_paragraph: Only three days after the Federal Government essentially turned down New York City's proposal to push Medicaid patients into managed-care programs, New York State officials said today that they planned to press the Clinton Administration to act quickly on their own proposal, which is more ambitious but similar to the city's. On Friday, the Federal Government said it would only accept New York City's proposal with several severe restrictions. The Giuliani administration rejected the conditions, saying it would have amounted to micro-management by Washington.

headline.main: In Capital, New York State Presses a Medicaid Care Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: AIDS care groups nationwide say they fear that the plan to give states more control over Medicaid, which pays the health costs of half of the nation's AIDS patients, will force thousands of people to forgo benefits like prescription drugs and home health care. Under the budget legislation passed by the House and the Senate last week, Medicaid spending would be slowed and the Federal Government would make block grants to the states, which would largely set their own standards for eligibility and care. The full Congress has yet to approve the budget bill, and President Clinton has vowed to veto any legislation with health care cuts that he regards as too severe.

headline.main: AIDS Groups Fear Loss Of Health Care Benefits

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, many doctors practiced their profession in a cut-and-dried way: they hung out shingles and tended to their patients. But the Medicare and Medicaid measures working their way through Congress could remold the role of many doctors, turning them into medical entrepreneurs and permitting them to engage in business enterprises that are now forbidden. The legislation is an important victory for the American Medical Association after years in which doctors have complained about losses of income and authority in the age of managed care.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Michael A. Stocker, president of Empire Blue Cross/Blue Shield, says New Yorkers need more information about managed care organizations (Op-Ed, Oct. 28). He's right. Mr. Stocker says legislation is needed. He's right again. Gov. George E. Pataki and I announced the patient-right-to-know bill last June, but the health maintenance organization industry lobbied unrelentingly against it.

docs.lead_paragraph: An independent research group has identified the health maintenance organizations with the highest levels of satisfied members in five areas around the nation in surveys conducted as part of new efforts by employers to determine which H.M.O.'s offer the highest-quality care. The health plans that were found most satisfactory were: Kaiser Permanente in Connecticut; Aetna Health Plan in greater Cleveland, Cigna Healthplans in greater Houston; Oxford Health Plans in New Jersey, and Kaiser Permanente in Southern California. Oxford won highest rating for metropolitan New York in the research group's survey of a single region last year.

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH the school year well under way, high school sophomores may be turning their thoughts to exchange programs for next year. Sometimes local teachers can provide leadership in this area, but even where they do, parents justifiably remain concerned about the quality, stability and financing of programs, or even the possibility that their children may be stranded far from home. The nonprofit Council on Standards for International Educational Travel in Leesburg, Va., which appraises student-exchange programs based in the United States, has just published the 1995-96 advisory list, its 11th annual reference. This lists high school programs that sought evaluation, paying a minimum of $550 as a fee, and have been approved by the evaluation committee.

docs.lead_paragraph: AS the Republican revolution proceeded last week, it became increasingly clear that its most enduring legacy may not be the curbs on Federal spending that have attracted most of the attention so far. More likely it will be the shift of power to state capitals, a fundamental realignment that is already unleashing unpredictable new forces. Limits on Federal spending can easily be lifted if they pinch too tight, or if Democrats gain more seats in Congress. But it will be practically impossible to re-create the vast web of Federal laws and regulations that govern Medicaid and welfare programs if the Federal requirements they are swept away this year as the Republicans propose.

docs.lead_paragraph: HE DARTS AROUND HER MANHATTAN HOTEL suite waving a can of Lysol, which she carries in her purse for occasions like this. Dusty Springfield, the 56-year-old pop legend and former convent-school girl, has been caught sneaking a smoke. "It's so impolite of me," she says, still attacking the offending odor, gesticulating the way she used to when she sang "You Don't Have to Say You Love Me," the spasmodic ballad that was her biggest hit. Well, not impolite really, just a little . . . impossible. She's a singer, after all, the finest pop vocalist Britain has ever produced. What is she doing despoiling her voice with nicotine clouds, especially when she's just released her first album in the United States in 13 years, "A Very Fine Love"?
